Final Checkpoint Study Guide: EXPRESS

Express Docs: https://expressjs.com/en/4x/api.html#app EXPRESS : INTIAL SETUP

Making middleware match (verb & URI) App.use, app.all
Importing and syncing the db
Sending static files

   const express = require('express');
 2 const path = require('path');

   const morgan = require('morgan'); //logging the requests and responses
   const bodyParser = require('body-parser'); //parsing the req/res

 6 //require in the main db file
   const db = require('./db')

 9 const app = express(); //creating the link to express

   //starting up the server

   const server = app.listen(8080, ()=> console.log('listening on port 8080'));
13 // app.listen() takes the port number and a callback function

   //calling sync on db will allow for the connection to be made.

   db.sync().then() => console.log("database is sycned")
17

   //app.use means for all incoming requests use these routes
20 app.use(morgan('dev')) // logging the middleware

   //how to serve up static files

   app.use(express.static(path.join(__dirname, '..', 'node_modules')))
24

   // body parsing middleware

   app.use(bodyParser.json());
27 app.use(bodyParser.urlencoded({ extended: true }));
28
29 // 'API' routes all backend routes sends to the index.js in the api folder.
30 app.use('/api', require('./api'));

31

EXPRESS-SEQUELIZE : ACCESS INFORMATION FROM REQUEST

GET VS PUT VS DELETE VS POST req.body vs. req.params vs req.query

Only PUT and POST have a req.body GET and DELETE do not!
req.params : part of our URI in the request and in our middleware (:postId) req.query: part of the URI but not in middleware (?dks:dlks);

sending status and sending responses error handling

   // 404 middleware

33 app.use((req, res, next) =>
     path.extname(req.path).length > 0 ?

       res.status(404).send('Not found') :

next() 37 ); 

   // error handling endware

40 app.use((err, req, res, next) =>
     res.status(err.status || 500).send(err.message || 'Internal server error.')

); 

   const router = require('express').Router();
 2 module.exports = router;

   //for redirecting to another file with / routes use:

 5
   router.use('/nextroute', require'./nextroute')

   //router.VERB('/URI', callback function)

 9 router.get('/', function(req,res,next)){
     Model.findAll()

     //gets the information and sends a response using json

     .then(posts => res.json(posts))
13   .catch(next);

} 

16 //GET = retriving information
   router.get('/posts/:postId', function(req,res,next)){

     const postId = req.params.postId

     //the id is coming from the req that was sent in

20   Model.findById(postId)
     .then(post => res.json(post))

22   .catch(next);
23 }
24
25 //PUT = updating information

   router.put('/post/:postId', function(req, res, next)){
       const postId = req.params.postId

28     Model.findById(postId)
       .then(message => message.update(req.body))
       //after finding the post to edit you can call update on the instance and add in the

req.body 

31     .catch(next)
   }

34 //DELETE = deleting a row of information
   router.delete('/post/:postId', function(req,res,next)){

     //find the instance first then delete it

     Model.findById(postId)
38   .then(foundPost => {

       return foundPost.destroy();
     })

     .catch(next);
42 }

   //can also delete this way

45
   router.delete('/people/:peopleId', function(req,res,next)){

     //find the instance first then delete it

     Model.destroy({where: {id:peopleId}})
49   //send a status of 202 if it worked

     .then( ()=> { res.sendStatus(202); } )
     //send a message of error when it fails
     .catch(err => { res.status(err.status).send(err.message)});

53 } 

   //POST = creating a new row

56 router.post('/posts', function(req,res,next){
     Model.create(req.body)
     .then( post => res.json(post).status(201).end() )
     //if doing just res.status() need a .end() after

60 .catch(next); })
